awd_titl_txt: A new mechanism for Mode water formation at a thermohaline ocean front
awd_abstract_narration:
In every ocean basin, on the equatorward side of major ocean fronts, layers of weakly stratified waters with nearly homogeneous properties are found. These so-called "mode waters" play an important role in the coupled ocean-atmosphere system by sequestering and releasing heat and carbon dioxide on interannual timescales and by affecting the large-scale circulation through shaping the potential vorticity field. Current climate models have difficulties accurately forming mode waters with the correct temperature and salinity properties, which is a concern given their influence on interannual ocean and climate variability. The mechanisms explaining their formation are not well understood but appear to be shaped by the dynamics of the ocean fronts that mark their poleward extent. A new mode water formation mechanism that has a clear connection to fronts and involves cabbeling, submesoscale lateral mixing, and frontogenesis will be explored. Cabbeling refers to the process by which two water masses of equal density but different temperature and salinity are mixed to create a new, denser water mass, as a result of nonlinearities in the equation of state for seawater. The theory that forms the basis of this project suggests that the properties of mode waters are influenced by cabbeling at fronts. The dynamics necessarily involves submesoscale processes, which have received much attention in recent years, but in the framework of a linear equation of state. The coupling between submesoscale motions and cabbeling through changes in density has the potential for new, rich physics that will be explored in this project. The expected findings should help inform strategies to improve the simulation of mode waters in ocean circulation and climate models and should be important for quantifying the flux of nutrients at the fronts that mark gyre boundaries. The project includes mentoring and support of a promising postdoctoral researcher. A high school science teacher will be given training on laboratory demonstrations that illustrate the physics of the ocean, atmosphere, and climate that can be incorporated in their courses.

 A simple two-dimension model for the water mass transformation due to cabbeling at a thermohaline front forced by frontogenetic strain and equilibrated by lateral mixing correctly predicts the isopycnal layers where mode waters are observed to reside and suggests that the mechanism could be responsible for persistent, hence significant, mode water formation. This project will test and extend the simple model using a more complete theory and two sets of numerical simulations designed to study the process on scales spanning the width of a basin to the width of a front. The theory will consider partially compensated fronts and use the semi-geostrophic equations to capture the feedback of secondary circulations on frontogenesis and quantify its effect on cabbeling. The objectives of the basin-scale simulations are to test the theoretical prediction for mode water formation in a three-dimensional, double-gyre circulation and to explore the role of lateral mixing and cabbeling in setting the T-S relation of mode waters. The second set of simulations will be configured with a thermohaline front collocated with a sheet of cyclonic vorticity modeled after flow observed in the Gulf Stream. The submesoscale shear instabilities that develop and the isopycnal mixing of temperature and salt they induce will be studied to determine how cabbeling should be parameterized via an eddy diffusivity. In addition, the potential dynamical feedbacks of cabbeling on the submesoscale instabilities will be investigated.

por.por_cntn:
In every ocean basin, on the equatorward side of major ocean fronts, large volumes of weakly stratified waters with nearly homogeneous properties are found. These so-called "mode waters" play an important role in the coupled ocean-atmosphere system by sequestering and releasing heat and carbon dioxide on interannual timescales and by affecting the large-scale circulation through shaping the potential vorticity field. Current climate models have difficulties accurately forming mode waters with the correct temperature and salinity properties, which is a concern given their influence on interannual ocean and climate variability. The models also have difficulty in predicting the seasonal decline in mode water volume in the spring and summer. The mechanisms explaining mode water formation and destruction are not well understood but appear to be shaped by the dynamics of the ocean fronts that mark their poleward extent. This project explored the physics of mode water formation and destruction mechanisms involving submesoscale (i.e. with length scales between 100m -10 km in the horizontal) processes at fronts which are not resolved in climate models yet can influence the dynamics of the large-scale circulation and hence climate.

 

Ocean fronts are defined by sharp jumps in temperature and salinity. Part of these temperature and salinity (T-S) changes are density compensated, that is they do not result in a density contrast across the front.  Interestingly, mixing these compensated T-S contrasts across a front makes the water denser because the density of sea water is a nonlinear function of temperature, a phenomenon that is known as cabbeling. Observations reveal that the density-compensated T-S contrasts at fronts tend to be largest near the sea surface and decrease with depth. This implies that lateral mixing at fronts should make near-surface waters denser via cabbeling and transport water into certain density layers at depth. As this happens, these layers fill in volume and thus form a mode water. A theory was developed to predict the mode water formation rate via this process and its dependence on the properties of fronts and their circulation. Numerical simulations were used to test the theory and illustrate that cabbeling-driven mode water formation can result in formation rates of order 0.1-1x106 m3/s, which are consistent with the theoretical predictions and are of similar magnitude to annually-averaged formation rates of mode waters observed in the ocean.  Unlike the theory, however, the simulations resolve rather than parameterize the submesoscale eddies that drive lateral mixing and cabbeling at fronts and hence provide insights into the detailed dynamics of this process. The simulations also shed light on how the particular temperature and salinity of a mode water is set. They reveal that the properties of the water masses that bound a front greatly influence the temperature-salinity (T-S) relation of the resulting mode water.  For fronts that are biased cold and fresh or warm and salty, the resulting mode water reflect this bias. Interestingly, the T-S relation of the resulting mode water is very similar to that of the bounding water mass that generates the bias. This is a feature that is seen in observed mode waters, and in the simulations can be explained by the combined effects of lateral mixing and densification by cabbeling.

 

The second objective of this project was to understand how mode waters are destroyed during the early spring when they restratify. At this time of year, the regions where mode waters are found are teeming with submesoscale fronts and eddies. Theory and numerical simulations were used to illustrate how boundary layer turbulence acting on these submesoscale processes can efficiently restratify the upper ocean and effectively destroy mode water. As part of the project, scalings for the restratification by boundary layer turbulence and submesoscale flows were derived and were verified using high-resolution numerical simulations. While these simulations were run with idealized flow configurations, the impact of this submesoscale physics on mode water destruction was illustrated using a high-resolution realistic model of the North Atlantic Subtropical Mode Water (Eighteen Degree Water), where it was demonstrated that restratification by submesoscale processes reduces the rate of mode water formation by a factor of ~2 and shortens the annual period of mode water formation by ~3 weeks. Submesoscale processes thus provide a direct link between small-scale boundary layer turbulence and the gyre-scale circulation, through their effect on mode water formation and destruction, with implications for understanding the variability and biogeochemical properties of ocean mode waters globally.
